title: 106_hr1942
content:
SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that free trade agreements benefit citizens by improving income and prosperity, APEC aims for free and open trade by 2020, economic growth in the Pacific Rim is crucial for the US, and the Asian financial crisis is a concern. The strategic and economic interests of the United States in the Pacific Rim region are impacted by the financial crisis in Asia, leading to a disruption in export growth. Free trade agreement negotiations are crucial in the current world economy to combat protectionist policies and open markets for US goods and services. Countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore are allies in promoting economic growth through trade liberalization. Coordination with these countries is essential for building closer ties in the region. Australia, Singapore, and the United States work together to increase economic growth through trade liberalization in organizations like the World Trade Organization and APEC. Building closer ties with friendly countries will benefit trade negotiations in the Asia-Pacific region. Bilateral trade agreements can positively influence multilateral and regional trade negotiations by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries aim to enhance cooperation, resolve disputes effectively, and stabilize bilateral trade balances through market access and mutual understanding. SEC. 2. UNITED STATES TRADE POLICY WITH ELIGIBLE PACIFIC RIM COUNTRIES. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. Nontariff barriers include regulatory obstacles, lack of intellectual property protection, and unfair trade practices. The President will identify eligible Pacific Rim countries and initiate consultations within 60 days of the Act's enactment. If feasible, a ministerial meeting will be requested within 60 days after consultations to discuss conditions for formal trade agreement negotiations. The International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment to products from eligible countries within 6 months of each ministerial meeting. The Ministerial Meeting Recommendations will be discussed within 60 days after consultations to consider conditions for formal trade agreement negotiations. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement. The council analyzes trade practices, customs laws, economic data, disputes, and issues a report within 6 months. The President suggests forming a council to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement, analyzing trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and disputes. The council will issue a report within 6 months, focusing on the benefits, adverse effects, and dispute settlement mechanisms of the agreement. The President will determine the feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will determine the feasibility of free trade agreements with eligible Pacific Rim countries, considering factors like WTO membership and expressed interest in negotiations. The determination will be based on reports from bilateral councils and advice from the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy Negotiations. The President will consider various factors when determining the feasibility of free trade agreements with eligible countries, including WTO membership, interest in negotiations, trade liberalization efforts, alignment with US trade policy objectives, participation in WTO activities, and efforts to improve export performance. The country:
- Demonstrates commitment to US objectives in WTO negotiations
- Works to eliminate export and local content requirements
- Seeks harmonization of domestic and international standards in APEC
- Increases economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses
- Eliminates barriers to trade in services
- Provides national treatment for foreign direct investment
- Accommodates US market access objectives
- Resolves trade disputes with the US
- Benefits from improved dispute settlement mechanisms in bilateral trade relations with the US The country aims to enhance its bilateral trade relationship with the United States by eliminating trade barriers and improving dispute settlement mechanisms. The President must consult with specific Congressional committees regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines eligible Pacific Rim countries as WTO members and APEC economies.
